Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters affecting the parties’ minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable Massachusetts case law, including Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for making and explaining custody determinations in the context of domestic violence, not with the court’s ongoing or continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting-time matters under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Section 28 is mentioned only indirectly via reference to related custody statutes, and the case does not discuss modification, retention, or continuation of jurisdiction. Therefore, Custody of Vaughn does not provide authority for the specific continuing-jurisdiction proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ … We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made attending specifically to the effects of domestic violence on the child….”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: Felton v. Felton deals with a sole‑custody arrangement and the limits a court may place on a noncustodial parent’s religious instruction during visitation. It does not address the concept of joint legal custody, nor does it articulate any rule that “significant decisions” (education, medical care, major activities) must be made jointly. The opinion focuses on best interests, religious freedom, and evidentiary standards for restricting a noncustodial parent’s religious activities, not on shared decision‑making authority between parents.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “After divorce, custody of the two minor children of the marriage was granted to the mother, with visitation rights to the father… The law, however, tolerates and even encourages up to a point the child’s exposure to the religious influences of both parents although they are divided in their faiths… In all events, the question that comes to the courts is whether, in particular circumstances, such exposures are disturbing a child to its substantial injury, physical or emotional…”

It merely recites the statutory language and resolves a relocation/physical custody dispute. Thus, Yannas provides background on what joint legal custody means but does not itself articulate or apply a rule about joint decision‑making in the manner claimed in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife.”

Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of custody and parenting arrangements upon a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Rosenberg squarely addresses modification standards under § 28, expressly stating that a judge may modify custody upon finding a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests. Although the main dispute involved support and Social Security benefits, the court’s discussion of the custody modification standard directly supports citing Rosenberg for the legal principle that a material and substantial change affecting the child’s welfare is required to modify custody/parenting provisions under § 28.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings… The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for awarding child custody and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the best interests and welfare of the child, not as punishment for a parent. It does not address parenting time/visitation interference, unilateral decisions about extracurricular activities, or how such conduct might undermine the stability or predictability of an existing parenting-time order. Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody determination between unmarried parents and focuses on the best interests of the child, the mother’s obstruction of the father’s joint legal custody, and general parenting quality. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a parent’s unilateral scheduling of activities during the other parent’s weekend constitutes substantial interference with parenting time or undermines the stability of an existing order.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the mother has “dismissed the need of [the child] for a [f]ather” and has “thwarted his joint legal custody at every turn.” “She has denied him information about and input into the most important decisions and events concerning the child: medical issues, hospitalizations, attendance at preschool, selection of pre-school educational programs, all to the detriment of [the child].” The judge found that the mother believes that she alone can make important decisions in the child’s life.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The persistent pattern of unilateral scheduling, disparagement, and blame-shifting has eroded the parties’ ability to effectively exercise joint legal custody and to co‑parent cooperatively, which is a prerequisite for successful joint decision‑making under Massachusetts law.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the mother’s unilateral right to relocate prior to an adjudication of paternity. It does not address joint legal custody, co‑parenting dynamics, or any requirement under Massachusetts law that effective cooperation is a prerequisite for joint decision‑making. The cited text concerns removal/relocation and the timing/status of legal parentage, not breakdowns in joint custody due to disparagement or blame‑shifting.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “The Yannas factors apply to prevent one legal parent from unilaterally relocating with a child to another jurisdiction, thereby affecting the parental rights of the other legal parent. That analysis is triggered only where the rights of two legal parents have been established prior to removal or attempted removal of the child from Massachusetts. … This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child, including the child’s welfare, happiness, and development.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: A modified order, as requested herein, will reduce conflict, ensure clearer decision‑making authority, preserve the Children’s stable primary residence with Plaintiff, and protect them from disparagement and divided loyalties, thereby serving their best interests under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31 and the above‑cited cases.
